property.name: log.dirs
property.description: A comma-separated list of one or more directories in which Kafka data is stored. Each new partition that is created will be placed in the directory which currently has the fewest partitions.

property.name: port
property.description: The port on which the server accepts client connections.

property.name: zookeeper.connect
property.description: Zookeeper also allows you to add a "chroot" path which will make all kafka data for this cluster appear under a particular path. This is a way to setup multiple Kafka clusters or other applications on the same zookeeper cluster. To do this give a connection string in the form hostname1:port1,hostname2:port2,hostname3:port3/chroot/path which would put all this cluster's data under the path /chroot/path. Note that consumers must use the same connection string.

property.name: message.max.bytes
property.description: The maximum size of a message that the server can receive. It is important that this property be in sync with the maximum fetch size your consumers use or else an unruly producer will be able to publish messages too large for consumers to consume.

property.name: num.network.threads
property.description: The number of network threads that the server uses for handling network requests. You probably don't need to change this.

property.name: num.io.threads
property.description: The number of I/O threads that the server uses for executing requests. You should have at least as many threads as you have disks.

property.name: queued.max.requests
property.description: The number of requests that can be queued up for processing by the I/O threads before the network threads stop reading in new requests.

property.name: socket.send.buffer.bytes
property.description: The SO_SNDBUFF buffer the server prefers for socket connections.

property.name: socket.receive.buffer.bytes
property.description: The SO_RCVBUFF buffer the server prefers for socket connections.

property.name: socket.request.max.bytes
property.description: The maximum request size the server will allow. This prevents the server from running out of memory and should be smaller than the Java heap size.

property.name: num.partitions
property.description: The default number of partitions per topic.

property.name: log.segment.bytes
property.description: The maximum request size the server will allow. This prevents the server from running out of memory and should be smaller than the Java heap size.

property.name: log.roll.hours
property.description: This setting will force Kafka to roll a new log segment even if the log.segment.bytes size has not been reached.

property.name: log.retention.bytes
property.description: The amount of data to retain in the log for each topic-partitions. Note that this is the limit per-partition so multiply by the number of partitions to get the total data retained for the topic. Also note that if both log.retention.hours and log.retention.bytes are both set we delete a segment when either limit is exceeded.

property.name: log.retention.hours
property.description: The number of hours to keep a log segment before it is deleted, i.e. the default data retention window for all topics. Note that if both log.retention.hours and log.retention.bytes are both set we delete a segment when either limit is exceeded.

property.name: log.cleanup.interval.mins
property.description: The frequency in minutes that the log cleaner checks whether any log segment is eligible for deletion to meet the retention policies.

property.name: log.retention.check.interval.ms
property.description: The frequency in milliseconds that the log cleaner checks whether any log segment is eligible for deletion to meet the retention policies.

property.name: log.index.size.max.bytes
property.description: The maximum size in bytes we allow for the offset index for each log segment. Note that we will always pre-allocate a sparse file with this much space and shrink it down when the log rolls. If the index fills up we will roll a new log segment even if we haven't reached the log.segment.bytes limit.

property.name: log.index.interval.bytes
property.description: The byte interval at which we add an entry to the offset index. When executing a fetch request the server must do a linear scan for up to this many bytes to find the correct position in the log to begin and end the fetch. So setting this value to be larger will mean larger index files (and a bit more memory usage) but less scanning. However the server will never add more than one index entry per log append (even if more than log.index.interval worth of messages are appended). In general you probably don't need to mess with this value.

property.name: auto.create.topics.enable
property.description: Enable auto creation of topic on the server. If this is set to true then attempts to produce, consume, or fetch metadata for a non-existent topic will automatically create it with the default replication factor and number of partitions.

property.name: controller.socket.timeout.ms
property.description: The socket timeout for commands from the partition management controller to the replicas.

property.name: controller.message.queue.size
property.description: The buffer size for controller-to-broker-channels

property.name: default.replication.factor
property.description: The default replication factor for automatically created topics.

property.name: replica.lag.time.max.ms
property.description: If a follower hasn't sent any fetch requests for this window of time, the leader will remove the follower from ISR (in-sync replicas) and treat it as dead.

property.name: replica.lag.max.messages
property.description: If a replica falls more than this many messages behind the leader, the leader will remove the follower from ISR and treat it as dead.

property.name: replica.socket.timeout.ms
property.description: The socket timeout for network requests to the leader for replicating data.

property.name: replica.socket.receive.buffer.bytes
property.description: The socket receive buffer for network requests to the leader for replicating data.

property.name: replica.fetch.max.bytes
property.description: The number of byes of messages to attempt to fetch for each partition in the fetch requests the replicas send to the leader.

property.name: replica.fetch.wait.max.ms
property.description: The maximum amount of time to wait time for data to arrive on the leader in the fetch requests sent by the replicas to the leader.

property.name: replica.fetch.min.bytes
property.description: Minimum bytes expected for each fetch response for the fetch requests from the replica to the leader. If not enough bytes, wait up to replica.fetch.wait.max.ms for this many bytes to arrive.

property.name: num.replica.fetchers
property.description: Number of threads used to replicate messages from leaders. Increasing this value can increase the degree of I/O parallelism in the follower broker.

property.name: replica.high.watermark.checkpoint.interval.ms
property.description: The frequency with which each replica saves its high watermark to disk to handle recovery.

property.name: fetch.purgatory.purge.interval.requests
property.description: The purge interval (in number of requests) of the fetch request purgatory.

property.name: producer.purgatory.purge.interval.requests
property.description: The purge interval (in number of requests) of the producer request purgatory.

property.name: zookeeper.session.timeout.ms
property.description: Zookeeper session timeout. If the server fails to heartbeat to zookeeper within this period of time it is considered dead. If you set this too low the server may be falsely considered dead; if you set it too high it may take too long to recognize a truly dead server.

property.name: zookeeper.connection.timeout.ms
property.description: The maximum amount of time that the client waits to establish a connection to zookeeper.

property.name: zookeeper.sync.time.ms
property.description: How far a ZK follower can be behind a ZK leader.

property.name: controlled.shutdown.max.retries
property.description: Number of retries to complete the controlled shutdown successfully before executing an unclean shutdown.

property.name: controlled.shutdown.retry.backoff.ms
property.description: Backoff time between shutdown retries.

property.name: kafka.metrics.reporters
property.description: kafka ganglia metrics reporter and kafka timeline metrics reporter

property.name: kafka.ganglia.metrics.reporter.enabled
property.description: kafka ganglia metrics reporter enable

property.name: kafka.ganglia.metrics.host
property.description: Ganglia host

property.name: kafka.ganglia.metrics.port
property.description: Ganglia port

property.name: kafka.ganglia.metrics.group
property.description: Ganglia group name

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.reporter.enabled
property.description: Kafka timeline metrics reporter enable

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.hosts
property.description: Timeline host

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.port
property.description: Timeline port

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.protocol
property.description: Timeline protocol(http or https)

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.truststore.path
property.description: Location of the trust store file.

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.truststore.type
property.description: Optional. Default value is "jks".

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.truststore.password
property.description: Password to open the trust store file.

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.reporter.sendInterval
property.description: Timeline metrics reporter send interval

property.name: kafka.timeline.metrics.maxRowCacheSize
property.description: Timeline metrics reporter send interval

property.name: listeners
property.description: host and port where kafka broker will be accepting connections. localhost will be substituted with hostname.

property.name: controlled.shutdown.enable
property.description: Enable controlled shutdown of the broker. If enabled, the broker will move all leaders on it to some other brokers before shutting itself down. This reduces the unavailability window during shutdown.

property.name: auto.leader.rebalance.enable
property.description: Enables auto leader balancing. A background thread checks and triggers leader balance if required at regular intervals

property.name: num.recovery.threads.per.data.dir
property.description: The number of threads per data directory to be used for log recovery at startup and flushing at shutdown

property.name: min.insync.replicas
property.description: define the minimum number of replicas in ISR needed to satisfy a produce request with required.acks=-1 (or all)

property.name: leader.imbalance.per.broker.percentage
property.description: The ratio of leader imbalance allowed per broker. The controller would trigger a leader balance if it goes above this value per broker. The value is specified in percentage.

property.name: leader.imbalance.check.interval.seconds
property.description: The frequency with which the partition rebalance check is triggered by the controller

property.name: offset.metadata.max.bytes
property.description: The maximum size for a metadata entry associated with an offset commit

property.name: offsets.load.buffer.size
property.description: Batch size for reading from the offsets segments when loading offsets into the cache.

property.name: offsets.topic.replication.factor
property.description: The replication factor for the offsets topic (set higher to ensure availability). To ensure that the effective replication factor of the offsets topic is the configured value, the number of alive brokers has to be at least the replication factor at the time of the first request for the offsets topic. If not, either the offsets topic creation will fail or it will get a replication factor of min(alive brokers, configured replication factor).

property.name: offsets.topic.num.partitions
property.description: The number of partitions for the offset commit topic (should not change after deployment)

property.name: offsets.topic.segment.bytes
property.description: The offsets topic segment bytes should be kept relatively small in order to facilitate faster log compaction and cache loads

property.name: offsets.topic.compression.codec
property.description: Compression codec for the offsets topic - compression may be used to achieve \"atomic\" commits. Default is NoCompression. For Gzip add value 1 , SnappyCompression add value 2, LZ4CompressionCodec 3.

property.name: offsets.retention.minutes
property.description: Log retention window in minutes for offsets topic

property.name: offsets.retention.check.interval.ms
property.description: Frequency at which to check for stale offsets

property.name: offsets.commit.timeout.ms
property.description: Offset commit will be delayed until all replicas for the offsets topic receive the commit or this timeout is reached. This is similar to the producer request timeout.

property.name: offsets.commit.required.acks
property.description: The required acks before the commit can be accepted. In general, the default (-1) should not be overridden

property.name: delete.topic.enable
property.description: Enables delete topic. Delete topic through the admin tool will have no effect if this config is turned off

property.name: compression.type
property.description: Specify the final compression type for a given topic. This configuration accepts the standard compression codecs ('gzip', 'snappy', lz4). It additionally accepts 'uncompressed' which is equivalent to no compression; and 'producer' which means retain the original compression codec set by the producer.

property.name: external.kafka.metrics.exclude.prefix
property.description: Exclude metrics starting with these prefixes from being collected.

property.name: external.kafka.metrics.include.prefix
property.description: These metrics would be included even if the exclude prefix omits them.

property.name: authorizer.class.name
property.description: Kafka authorizer class
